html.p: What: Process events as they stream through, adding summary statistics to each event either individually or in a "window".

ol.li: There's a lot of options you can use for how to reset statistics, change windows sizes and so on. We'll touch on a few of these but see the docs!
Options for window=<integer> and time_window=<span-length> are probably the most commonly used.

html.p: How: |streamstats [all kinds of options here] function(field) [AS field], function(field) [AS field], ... [BY field...]
Why: Allows you to do all sorts of analysis that isn't easily done without it. Time-window math/counts, running counts, etc.

So What: Streamstats, especially with time or other windows, is really powerful and solves problems that are simply unsolveable without it. I also believe streamstats is probably the neatest command in all of Splunk.
We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup
While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is:
Also, we'll use some data from _internal: index=_internal

panel.title: How many cars sold by day?

search.query: |inputlookup rich_and_dave_cars.csv | bin _time span=1d | stats sum(cars) AS "Cars Sold By Day" by _time

panel.title: How many cars did each salesperson sell each day?

search.query: |inputlookup rich_and_dave_cars.csv | bin _time span=1d | stats sum(cars) AS "Cars Sold By Day" by salesperson, _time

panel.title: actions vs. levels in _internal
panel.html: Does a two-level stats, counting how many results for each combination of status (200, 404,...) and user (limiting to first 10 results)

search.query: index=_internal status=* user=* earliest="-15m@m" latest="@m" | stats count by status user

panel.title: actions vs. levels in _internal
panel.html: Here we take an average and a 95th percentile for action_time_ms, and list those by savedsearch_name. (Filtering out where there's 4 or fewer results, because "95th percentile" isn't very useful on small results)

search.query: index=_internal action_time_ms=* earliest="-4h@h" latest="@h" | stats count avg(action_time_ms) as action_time_ms_avg, perc95(action_time_ms) as action_time_ms_p95 by savedsearch_name | search count>=5 | fields - count

panel.title: NOT USING JOIN
panel.html: The Splunk command join is almost never what you want. Here's an example where you combine two completely different sets of data by using stats instead of join. The important point here is that the two searches on each side of the OR could be *any* two searches. If they share a common field, you use stats ... by to group them.

search.query: (index=_internal sourcetype=splunkd) OR (index=_internal sourcetype=scheduler) | stats sum(run_time) as total_run_time, sum(active_hist_searches) as active_hist_searches by user
